Description: Calcite vase in form of pregnant woman: shown standing with her knees slightly bent, holding a lute. Her hair is pulled back and falls just below her shoulders. At the back of the vase, the prominent handle loops from the base of the spout on the woman's head to her back at the level of her shoulder blades, just below the ends of her hair.
Curator's comments: Figure vases of stone are less common than those made of pottery. The stone versions generally represent nude pregnant women either standing or kneeling, and as a group they are much less detailed than their pottery counterparts. Bibliography: G. Robins, 'Women in Ancient Egypt' (Cambridge, Mass. 1993), p. 66, fig. 20; 'Art and Afterlife in Ancient Egypt' Japan, 1999-2000 [exhibition catalogue] (Japan, 1999), No 134.
Bibliographic references: Roehrig 2005 / Hatshepsut: From Queen to Pharaoh (169)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2005-2006 15 Oct-29 Jan, San Francisco, M H Young Memorial Museum, Hatshepsut 2006 20 Mar-9 Jul, New York, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Hatshepsut 2006 26 Aug-10 Dec, Fort Worth, Kimbell Museum of Art, Hatshepsut 2017-2018 13 Sep-15 Jan, Lens, Louvre, Musiques et sons antiques
